thread.title: Fire chiefs have tried to set the record straight over claims made about cash reserves by the Prime Minister

author: nechronicle
title: Fire chiefs have tried to set the record straight over claims made about cash reserves by the Prime Minister
text:
Fire chiefs have tried to set the record straight over claims made about cash reserves by the Prime Minister The issue was raised at Prime Minister's Questions by North East MP Sharon Hodgson Share Tyne and Wear Fire and Rescue Service (Image: newcastle chronicle) Get daily updates directly to your inbox Subscribe Thank you for subscribing We have more newsletters Show me See our privacy notice Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email
Fire chiefs have hit back after the Prime Minister appeared to dismiss funding concerns.
The issue was raised at Prime Minister's Questions (PMQs) on Wednesday by Washington and Sunderland West MP Sharon Hodgson.
Mrs Hodgson said current funding formulas don't work in areas like Wearside and risked leaving communities "perilously close to having unsafe fire and police services".
In response, Theresa May claimed Tyne and Wear Fire and Rescue Service (TWFRS) had had its funding increased this year and holds savings worth £25m - equivalent to 52% of its core spending power. Prime Minister Theresa May (Image: PA)
But speaking at a meeting in Sunderland to discuss proposed service cuts on Thursday night, Assistant Chief Fire Officer Alan Robson attempted to set the record straight.
He said: "We've got reserves of £28.5m and of this £24m is earmarked to meet specific programmes. Read More How will North East MPs vote on Brexit? Only one will back Theresa May's under-fire deal
"One thing we've got in train is the replacement of half of our fleet of fire engines.
"We've got to do that because some of our engines have been sweated a bit more than they should have been. Read More
"We usually replace them at the ten-year point, but through good servicing we've been able to extend that to 15.
"But now we've got replace that's coming from reserves.
"If we don't do that the engines start to cost us more money because they need more maintenance."
TWFRS has also earmarked up to £5m from its cash reserves for a new fire station in Hebburn . Like us on Facebook
